p: Parkin is an E3 ubiquitin ligase that serves a critical role in targeting proteins for degradation. It is also involved in the clearance of damaged mitochondria via autophagy and proteasomal mechanisms. Parkin is encoded by the PARK2 ( PRKN) gene, which is located on chromosome 6q25.2-q27, and spans >500 kb. It contains 12 exons, which translate to a protein of 465 amino acids ( 6). PARK2 variants appear to be responsible for PD pathogenesis, which was first reported in Japanese families in 1998( 6). According to the Human Gene Mutation Database, >300 pathogenic mutations have been identified in the PARK2 gene ( hgmd.cf.ac.uk/ac/gene.php?gene=PRKN; accessed July 2020), most of which are gross deletions, followed by missense mutations, gross insertions, small deletions, splicing defects and small insertions. Although the mechanism by which loss of parkin function results in dopaminergic cell death in PD is unclear, it is considered to involve the disruption of mitochondrial quality control ( 7).
